abstract: We have the First Communion, the bat mitzvah, the Sweet 16. Where are the rituals to celebrate the milestones of the other half of life?
snippet: We have the First Communion, the bat mitzvah, the Sweet 16. Where are the rituals to celebrate the milestones of the other half of life?
lead_paragraph: For some women, menopause is no big deal. Some say they barely notice it. My mother, long ago, described her menopause this way: “My periods just started gettin’ lighter and lighter, and my harmones  settled down, and then one day … pfft! It was over.”

headline.main: All Praise the Women of Menopause
headline.print_headline: All Praise the Women of Menopause

abstract: Losing Nantucket taught me that I didn’t have a right to a round-trip ticket to the world’s wild edge.
snippet: Losing Nantucket taught me that I didn’t have a right to a round-trip ticket to the world’s wild edge.
lead_paragraph: For 13 summers, my father worked as the tennis pro at a yacht club on Nantucket.

abstract: Coming to understand a life’s peculiar loneliness.
snippet: Coming to understand a life’s peculiar loneliness.
lead_paragraph: I was 6 years old when I first heard I had a twin brother. My family — my father, my mother and I — had recently crossed the border from Mexico to settle in Brownsville, Tex. My maternal grandmother, Mamá Concha, lived there, too, in a little house of her own. I was always left in her care when my parents went out for a late night.

abstract: On the last day of my husband’s life, I combed his hair for the first time.
snippet: On the last day of my husband’s life, I combed his hair for the first time.
lead_paragraph: These weeks after the passing of my husband, Stuart, I often think of Joan Didion and her book “The Year of Magical Thinking,” and about how her beloved husband, John Gregory Dunne, died suddenly of cardiac arrest while sitting in his living room.

abstract: Girls who dress as pirates for Halloween are spunky. Girls who dress as Darth Vader make people uncomfortable.
snippet: Girls who dress as pirates for Halloween are spunky. Girls who dress as Darth Vader make people uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: There are many possible explanations for why my 5-year-old daughter has yet again asked if she can change her name to Sam. Sam can also be a girl’s name, I explain hopefully. No, she clarifies, sighing at the dullard she has been given for a mother. She wants to be Sam the boy’s name.

abstract: A New York City tunnel worker, he always relied on his body, until he was told he had Parkinson’s.
snippet: A New York City tunnel worker, he always relied on his body, until he was told he had Parkinson’s.
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon before my college graduation in 1999, there was a ceremony for graduates who were getting department prizes. My father was a New York City tunnel worker (a “sandhog”) and at that time he was working on Roosevelt Island, a 20-minute drive from Barnard’s campus. He always showered before leaving the job site, and on that day he’d brought khakis, a freshly pressed shirt and tie and the new jacket my mother had gotten him for his 55th birthday. I remember what he was wearing because it was the first time I noticed him holding a handkerchief, which he used throughout the ceremony to dab the corners of his mouth. After, when we were discussing where to have dinner, I spotted a narrow river of saliva traveling down the side of his chin.

abstract: People drop dead in hallways all the time. But suspicion makes for a much better story.
snippet: People drop dead in hallways all the time. But suspicion makes for a much better story.
lead_paragraph: The green metal file box was about the size and shape of an ammunition case. It was scuffed and serious-looking and packed tight with personal letters and papers that had belonged to my grandfather, who died in 1989. The line in the family had always been that he “did intelligence work in Washington after the war.” This file box gave up a better story: My grandfather was an operations officer with the C.I.A. from January 1948 to August 1951. But that revelation brought up another question: Why only three years? I went back through the brittle and yellowing letters in the file box, looking for anything that might explain the brevity of my grandfather’s spying career. I wouldn’t need much; I have a fertile imagination.

headline.main: A Scandal at the C.I.A. Maybe.

abstract: I wanted to be an artist, but I didn’t want to have to sell hoodies with my face on them.
snippet: I wanted to be an artist, but I didn’t want to have to sell hoodies with my face on them.
lead_paragraph: Not long before my first album was released in 2005, I spent a summer in Russia interviewing small business owners. An American microfinance organization had sent me there to gather rosy statistics and uplifting stories about how their loans had improved the lives of this new crop of entrepreneurs.

abstract: Transplanting the stool from one person into the digestive tract of another seems, well, repulsive, but sometimes it makes a lot of sense.
snippet: Transplanting the stool from one person into the digestive tract of another seems, well, repulsive, but sometimes it makes a lot of sense.
lead_paragraph: This spring I saved a friend from a terrible illness, maybe even death. No, I didn’t donate a kidney or a piece of my lung. I did it with my stool.

abstract: Descendants of slave owners and of slaves are recognizing their connections. In my family, it’s especially complicated.
snippet: Descendants of slave owners and of slaves are recognizing their connections. In my family, it’s especially complicated.
lead_paragraph: EL CERRITO, Calif. — I learned about her through the comments section of an article in Publisher’s Weekly. I had recently published a book of poems crafted out of family stories, and it had been written up, along with a brief interview. In the interview, I reckon with the complicated history of my family — I am a white descendant of Thomas Jefferson — and the fact that some of my ancestors were slave owners from 1670 until the Civil War.

abstract: A glimpse of New York City’s softer side.
snippet: A glimpse of New York City’s softer side.
lead_paragraph: I was the sick passenger on the No. 2 train, the one responsible for the line’s delay. It was I who kept New Yorkers from their destinations, and prompted the notice that thanked them for a quality they’re not known to have.

abstract: The Methodist choir director asked me to infuse my performance with the “Demon of Lust.” Fortunately, I knew a thing or two about possession.
snippet: The Methodist choir director asked me to infuse my performance with the “Demon of Lust.” Fortunately, I knew a thing or two about possession.
lead_paragraph: When I appeared at the dress rehearsal for “Life of Christ” wearing a pink sheet toga-style, Miss K., the Methodist choir director, took me aside.

headline.main: On Whoredom, Demonic Possession and Penitence

abstract: I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside.
snippet: I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — I spent many months, as a fetus, in a mental institution, listening to the world shuffling outside. I don’t know what meds were administered to me in that developing stage. I lived in the belly of a woman I would never know. But my relationship with something dubiously entitled mental health was already established.

abstract: Most of us customers are in late middle age. Soon we’ll be in knee braces, panting up the stairs to our dealer’s apartment.
snippet: Most of us customers are in late middle age. Soon we’ll be in knee braces, panting up the stairs to our dealer’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: His place is in one of those New York City neighborhoods that’s run-down but not dangerous. There’s no intercom in the building, so to open the downstairs door, you have to have your own key. He doesn’t take phone calls on either landline or cell. He doesn’t use the Internet. He stays off the grid.

abstract: I’m drawn to the old fairy tales, with less-than-happy endings.
snippet: I’m drawn to the old fairy tales, with less-than-happy endings.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, WASH. — My therapist calls me a “loyal skeptic,” a person who struggles to gain security and certainty in a world that she believes is inherently dangerous.

abstract: For one gardener, a lifetime of instant gratification yields to longer-term commitment.
snippet: For one gardener, a lifetime of instant gratification yields to longer-term commitment.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness for farmers. As a mere gardener, I don’t know how they do it. The heartbreak. My phlox had powdery mildew last summer and it about killed me. The worry. Was I applying the right mildew spray? The doubt. Had I read the Department of Agriculture’s official Plant Hardiness Zone Map correctly? Was Provincetown in Zone 7A? I had to remind myself that my life and livelihood did not depend on my phlox crop.

abstract: The policeman took a pained look at my mouth, and then asked if I had dental insurance.
snippet: The policeman took a pained look at my mouth, and then asked if I had dental insurance.
lead_paragraph: This happened in June 1997. It was around 2 in the morning. I was walking home, alone, from a party at a friend’s house. As I walked, I looked at the streetlights above, first with one eye closed, then the other, and it was as though the streetlights were winking at me. I’d been doing this for several blocks, long enough that the whole exercise had turned from time-passing to tiresome, but I kept doing because it seemed like bad luck to stop. I was drunk, obviously, although not very, just relatively — just a relatively drunk 28-year-old man who was in relatively good shape, feeling relatively happy. I had, at that time, a good head of hair, and a mouthful of good teeth. Out of all that information, only the last bit is especially relevant to this story.

headline.main: The Cost of Getting Kicked in the Face
headline.print_headline: The Cost of a Kick in the Face

abstract: The endless stream of prenatal data has changed a joyous experience into something ominous.
snippet: The endless stream of prenatal data has changed a joyous experience into something ominous.
lead_paragraph: Becoming a mother was so simple when I became a mother. Pregnancy was treated as a natural experience. You peed in a cup, and then once a month the obstetrician pressed his stethoscope against your belly and you watched his face for a smile.

abstract: A brain tumor the size of a blueberry has changed the way I get my bearings.
snippet: A brain tumor the size of a blueberry has changed the way I get my bearings.
lead_paragraph: The first time I fell, last autumn, I chalked it up to a combination of fatigue, clumsiness and bad luck. I had stolen some time away from work and chores, and I was goofing around with my 6-year-old, who was chasing me on his scooter. Attempting to escape, I leapt onto a log, which wobbled ever so slightly, and down I went.

headline.print_headline: The Brain Tumor As Zen Master

abstract: She left her daughters five suitcases, and a final, unspoken, piece of advice.
snippet: She left her daughters five suitcases, and a final, unspoken, piece of advice.
lead_paragraph: After our mother died last year at age 91, my four sisters and I gathered to clear out her apartment. We didn’t imagine the work would be onerous, since our mother — a modest, orderly person determined never to be a burden to her kids — had consciously downsized over the years as she and my father moved from their suburban home to a three-bedroom condo and then to a small apartment in a “senior residence.”

headline.main: What My Mother Wanted Us to Pack
headline.print_headline: What My Mother Wanted Us to Pack

abstract: It was St. Gregory the Great against the Immaculate Conception Youth Program.
snippet: It was St. Gregory the Great against the Immaculate Conception Youth Program.
lead_paragraph: We’re down by one, two outs, no men on, no men anywhere: This is bantam-division softball, and we’re 11-year-old girls. Michelle, our best player, is approaching the plate, helicoptering the bat over her head like this is the World Series and not just another Catholic Youth Organization game on a garbage-strewn blacktop in a far-flung corner of Queens.

abstract: The terrifying liberation of short-term memory loss.
snippet: The terrifying liberation of short-term memory loss.
lead_paragraph: I was 25 when I lost my memory. It happened on Jan. 16, 2012. I woke up, not knowing where I was. I was lying in bed, sure, but whose bed was it? There was no one in the room, no sound that I recognized: I was alone with my body.

abstract: “You’d be better off with chocolate and cola,” the dentist told me.
snippet: “You’d be better off with chocolate and cola,” the dentist told me.
lead_paragraph: I was into health food before it was cool. There were only two other people I knew who frequented my neighborhood health food store in the late ’80s: an emaciated man with a gray ponytail and a woman with a surprising amount of underarm hair, who smelled of B.O. and patchouli.

abstract: We were aware of our responsibility for our pet, yet we failed to take care.
snippet: We were aware of our responsibility for our pet, yet we failed to take care.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — I waited in the car outside of the school, knowing it was The Day, The Very Momentous Day. She appeared on the sidewalk, holding the box in both hands. Look what I have.

headline.main: The Value of a Life, Though Toxic and Tiny

abstract: I could save the birds, or at least try. I could do nothing for my father.
snippet: I could save the birds, or at least try. I could do nothing for my father.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t sent my father’s watch to be fixed since his death six months ago. I am scared to let it out of my grasp. For 45 years it circled his wrist: a silver-faced Accutron with a tuning-fork movement that I could hear humming when I brought Dad’s warm arm up to my ear. Its face tells me it stopped at 4:04 on the 27th. My father stopped at 6:04 on the 30th.

abstract: My grandmother thought she was ready to die. She was wrong.
snippet: My grandmother thought she was ready to die. She was wrong.
lead_paragraph: “I’m begging you,” pleaded my 93-year-old grandmother. “I want to quit while I’m ahead. I’m too tired. It’s been a good, solid run and I’m done.”

headline.main: When a Medical Proxy Saves a Life

abstract: A containership is like a space station, the oceans of the world an interplanetary void. Reaching the next port safely is always a cause for celebration.
snippet: A containership is like a space station, the oceans of the world an interplanetary void. Reaching the next port safely is always a cause for celebration.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Years ago, aboard my first ship as a young cadet, I noticed a man pacing along the bridge deck. I asked the third mate who he was.

abstract: Clothes made me a woman, whether I wanted them to or not.
snippet: Clothes made me a woman, whether I wanted them to or not.
lead_paragraph: I WORE a sweater with holes in it.

abstract: Medical-school students sometimes get carried away by their enthusiasm for the science of disease and forget the human suffering that comes with it.
snippet: Medical-school students sometimes get carried away by their enthusiasm for the science of disease and forget the human suffering that comes with it.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON

abstract: When I gave up law and started being a clown, I knew what it meant to be happy.
snippet: When I gave up law and started being a clown, I knew what it meant to be happy.
lead_paragraph: I was the envy of my 30-something friends in Palo Alto, Calif. I had my own law office right on California Avenue. People charged with crimes handed me cash, in advance, over a big oak desk. Occasionally, I’d make a couple of grand in an afternoon.

abstract: They may look like harmless birds to you, but they’re natural-born killers.
snippet: They may look like harmless birds to you, but they’re natural-born killers.
lead_paragraph: Ever since my mother joined the North American Bluebird Society, or NABS, she’s had it out for the English house sparrow — a bird that, when it isn’t devouring butterflies and yellow flowers, is pecking out the brains of bluebird mothers, dumping their lifeless bodies in the grass and then throwing their children out to die.

abstract: There was nothing I could do about an undergrad who frightened his classmates — and me.
snippet: There was nothing I could do about an undergrad who frightened his classmates — and me.
lead_paragraph: The undergraduate who had been writing poems about killing people showed up for his appointment in my office carrying a black canvas backpack. He was slim and dark-haired, his mouth torqued into an uneasy smile. I had spoken several times about his violent ramblings to the campus police and to the university’s office of mental health, and this was what they came up with: I should invite the student to my office and calmly begin a conversation with the following question: “Do you have a plan to harm yourself or anyone else?”

headline.print_headline: Was He a Killer or Just Sad?

abstract: The patch of dirt may have been covered in weeds and candy wrappers, but it was mine.
snippet: The patch of dirt may have been covered in weeds and candy wrappers, but it was mine.
lead_paragraph: Before purchasing a house in Brooklyn, I did not know the term “tree pit.” All I knew was that our house came with a small square plot of dirt out front, with a skinny, scraggly tree, and that it was up to me to maintain or ignore as I saw fit. At first I attended to it. I dug shovelfuls of dirt out of the pit. I weeded and plucked out the city detritus — rubber bands, candy bar wrappers and always more cigarette butts. Then I filled the hole with freshly purchased dirt and planted around the tree six low vinelike plants that the woman at the gardening store had said were good for ground cover. When I was done I admired my handiwork and immediately went inside to sterilize my hands.

headline.main: A Story of Gentrification in Brooklyn

abstract: Three months after giving birth, I found myself back in the hospital.
snippet: Three months after giving birth, I found myself back in the hospital.
lead_paragraph: “Anything I should know before I go home?” I asked the chief cardiologist, trying not to sound terrified.

abstract: What was I doing in America, when there was another land and a people that rightfully claimed me?
snippet: What was I doing in America, when there was another land and a people that rightfully claimed me?
lead_paragraph: When I was 7 years old my father bought me a Bag of Laughs. It was the early 1980s and, as with most every school morning in Lagos, Nigeria, we were stuck in traffic. My father was at the wheel, listening to Bob Marley on the eight-track. I sat in the back, staring at the street peddlers walking in between lanes jostling can openers, batteries and other random items at car windows.

abstract: When I came upon an ice bucket like hers, I didn’t even bargain.
snippet: When I came upon an ice bucket like hers, I didn’t even bargain.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, FLA. — My mother sat next to me on her sofa. She held a brass candlestick like a baton. “Put stickers on the things you’d like to have,” she said. “With your initials. So when I’m gone there’s no confusion.”

headline.main: Shopping for Antiques, Finding My Mother

abstract: What desperate, humiliating steps would I take in order to watch him play?
snippet: What desperate, humiliating steps would I take in order to watch him play?
lead_paragraph: It was March Madness, 2008, and I was not in my usual spot. Instead, I was on sabbatical on the South Island of New Zealand, where March comes in the autumn and basketball barely even registers as a sport. The only way to watch college games there was hunched over a flickering laptop screen, wearing earbuds and cursing your slow Internet connection.

headline.main: Steph Curry, the Prophet of Basketball

abstract: My mother was a refugee. She prospered in many ways, but she never lost her obsessions and apocalyptic thinking.
snippet: My mother was a refugee. She prospered in many ways, but she never lost her obsessions and apocalyptic thinking.
lead_paragraph: This was a summer of refugees, of walls, of border police, of daring journeys, of violence and death, sometimes of rescue, of separated families, each side not knowing what to do.

abstract: Italians once believed that craftsmanship and quality would save us from bankruptcy.
snippet: Italians once believed that craftsmanship and quality would save us from bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: MONTEMURLO, Italy

abstract: The priest blessed the baby, while the baby drooled on my arm.
snippet: The priest blessed the baby, while the baby drooled on my arm.
lead_paragraph: My 9-month-old son’s first time on a plane — a 10-hour journey from J.F.K. to Istanbul — was a disaster. The dry air of the cabin, the confinement and possibly some allergen on the in-flight menu all contributed to an unprecedented eruption of his eczema. It was demoralizing. His skin had been cracking and inflamed for months, but we had taken such pains with it — daily applications of heavy cream and austere dietary restrictions — in anticipation of introducing him to his relatives in Turkey.

abstract: Stories were my way in. Those figures in the cards became characters and plot points.
snippet: Stories were my way in. Those figures in the cards became characters and plot points.
lead_paragraph: I thought I could hold it together, that if I was broadcasting crazy it was at least in a glamorous silent-film-star kind of way. Perfect eyeliner surrounding a glint of madness. But obviously I wasn’t pulling it off. A friend intervened: “You’re freaking me out. I’m going to take you to a woman who has helped me out of tough times before.” She set up the appointment and I washed up at her tarot card reader’s Manhattan apartment.

abstract: Grown, with children of my own, I still dreamed of the abuser I once thought of as my father.
snippet: Grown, with children of my own, I still dreamed of the abuser I once thought of as my father.
lead_paragraph: My phone pinged.

abstract: On the eve of World War II, dad tried to get my grandfather to leave Germany. Why did he stay?
snippet: On the eve of World War II, dad tried to get my grandfather to leave Germany. Why did he stay?
lead_paragraph: There is a photograph of my father and grandfather, taken on Sunday, Aug. 27, 1939, at a spot overlooking the Rhine above the Lorelei Rock, where the chasm of the river tightens and the quickened flow makes a murmuring sound, which has mystical resonance for the Germans.

headline.main: The Last Train Before the War
headline.print_headline: The Last Train Before the War

abstract: I expected judgment and rebuke; instead, the rabbi told me a story.
snippet: I expected judgment and rebuke; instead, the rabbi told me a story.
lead_paragraph: I stood before the panel of rabbis, waiting to have a religious divorce conferred upon me. I was dressed as the Orthodox Jewish woman I was supposed to be, modestly, in a below-the-knee navy skirt and buttoned cardigan. But I felt exposed. What kind of shameful woman, I imagined the rabbis thinking, leaves her marriage; what kind of mother uproots her life?

headline.main: Divorced From My Husband, and My Faith

abstract: I saved her voice mails, realizing that any message could be the last.
snippet: I saved her voice mails, realizing that any message could be the last.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR — I had two saved messages, and both began the same way: “Hello, Rebecca. This is your grandmother. In Florida.”

abstract: Some children grow up feeling themselves to be the center of the universe, but I always knew I was a very tiny drop in the ocean of other people’s lives.
snippet: Some children grow up feeling themselves to be the center of the universe, but I always knew I was a very tiny drop in the ocean of other people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — At the start of the 1960s, my parents bought a corner shop and moved into the house above it with their five children. Ten years later, I, the accidental sixth, was born. By the time I was 9, my brother and sisters had grown up and either temporarily or permanently moved out, leaving behind them a museum of abandoned items. Cluttering every shelf and corner were forgotten cardigans, orphaned dolls, discarded purses and grayscale strips of pouting photo-booth faces.

abstract: Thanksgiving was my Korean family’s annual recommitment ceremony to the United States.
snippet: Thanksgiving was my Korean family’s annual recommitment ceremony to the United States.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in northern Minnesota, our family’s Thanksgivings were straight out of a Norman Rockwell painting.

abstract: What is it about being a widow that makes people pull away from me?
snippet: What is it about being a widow that makes people pull away from me?
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Noah, the world is made up of people in twosomes. I never thought much about the ark until my husband died one bright, sunny November morning almost one year ago.

abstract: I moved to Hudson, N.Y., to slow down and save money. I didn’t know I’d feel so lonely.
snippet: I moved to Hudson, N.Y., to slow down and save money. I didn’t know I’d feel so lonely.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, after a Pilates class in a studio above my former office, I rolled up a mat while the teacher spoke to another student, someone who seemed new in town — a potential friend. Lingering near the exercise bikes, I pretended to stretch, and then edged in to the conversation.

abstract: The artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
snippet: The artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
lead_paragraph: Three diagrams explaining how I fit in, from the Big Bang to the apocalypse. Read more »

abstract: The one thing that brings him back from the confusion of Alzheimer’s is beauty — the yellow rose bush and the bleeding heart.
snippet: The one thing that brings him back from the confusion of Alzheimer’s is beauty — the yellow rose bush and the bleeding heart.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Mom is doing makeup for the opera and Dad tags along. Beverly Sills has been brought in for the role of Lucia di Lammermoor and she has packed the house. Mom draws wrinkles on a tenor while Ms. Sills is called to the stage. The page is growing urgent. She’ll miss her entrance if she doesn’t show up soon. A crew member blows by and says they found her in the green room, apparently smitten to the point of distraction by a big strapping cowboy, my father. Bill Rotert, Mom would scold, later, on their drive home.

headline.main: The Mysteries of My Father’s Mind

abstract: He showed me the wild side of San Francisco. And then he showed me how to go home.
snippet: He showed me the wild side of San Francisco. And then he showed me how to go home.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, INDIA — In the mid ’90s, about five years after I had moved to the United States, I got rid of the part in my hair. It was the most daring thing I had ever done to my appearance. That side part, with me since my childhood in India, was the emblem of the well-behaved, well-groomed good boy, and I had carried it diligently into adulthood.

abstract: It wasn’t my heart that he broke.
snippet: It wasn’t my heart that he broke.
lead_paragraph: I was going out. I deserved it. I’d had lunch — one Diet Coke, two Marlboro Lights and a Chef’s Signature Lean Cuisine. I’d even done two luxurious miles in 24 minutes on the treadmill at the gym down the block. My stomach growled, angry for being empty, but I felt thin and attractive. There’s nothing more dangerous than a girl who feels thin and attractive.

abstract: Taking my son to see the glacier, while there’s still time.
snippet: Taking my son to see the glacier, while there’s still time.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, MONT. — Glacier National Park is melting, its sheets of ice predicted to vanish from the face of the earth by 2030. I’d known this for decades, and I did exactly nothing.

abstract: PTSD never goes away. On bad days, it’s so close you can’t breathe. On good days, it’s off in the distance like a gathering storm.
snippet: PTSD never goes away. On bad days, it’s so close you can’t breathe. On good days, it’s off in the distance like a gathering storm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Aug. 4, 2004, while in my Stryker combat vehicle battling insurgents for control of a street in Mosul, Iraq, I was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. The core of the rocket, a solid piece of metal only a few inches long, sliced open my stomach from right to left, filled my legs and face with shrapnel, tore my intestines, lacerated my liver, destroyed my spleen, punctured my diaphragm, flattened my lungs, shattered my ribs and ruptured discs in my back. As I struggled to remove my smoldering body armor, I watched my stomach tear open and my intestines begin to push their way out.

headline.main: A Soldier Fights Off the Cold
headline.print_headline: A Soldier Fights Off the Cold

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

abstract: My expat child doesn’t want to speak my native language.
snippet: My expat child doesn’t want to speak my native language.
lead_paragraph: MADRID

abstract: How can I part with anything?
snippet: How can I part with anything?
lead_paragraph: My husband, Stuart, died last June after a decade-long struggle with cancer. He was 77 years old, a former journalist and public relations executive, a marathon runner, and a man beloved and respected by family and friends.

abstract: I daydreamed that my book would end up in the White House library. But its real path was humbler, and more meaningful.
snippet: I daydreamed that my book would end up in the White House library. But its real path was humbler, and more meaningful.
lead_paragraph: I am not proud of it, but I will admit to having felt a twinge of envy when I read, over the holidays, of President Obama’s latest book purchases. How amazing would it be to have the president buy, and read, your novel?

abstract: At 35, I’ve been holding out for so long, how can I change now? And yet I have doubts.
snippet: At 35, I’ve been holding out for so long, how can I change now? And yet I have doubts.
lead_paragraph: When I was 20, one of my close friends was killed in a car crash. At the funeral, as I watched her coffin carried down the aisle, another friend leaned over to whisper: “At least she wasn’t a virgin.”

headline.main: Does My Virginity Have a Shelf Life?
headline.print_headline: Does My Virginity Have a Shelf Life?

abstract: My husband made me swear to forget the disease that killed him. No fund-raising, no telethons, not even a bake sale.
snippet: My husband made me swear to forget the disease that killed him. No fund-raising, no telethons, not even a bake sale.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Like most people, I was impressed and amused by the A.L.S. ice bucket challenge — that so many people got involved and that both funds and awareness were raised. But I was also conflicted.

abstract: I never appreciated great tennis, until I could no longer afford a seat.
snippet: I never appreciated great tennis, until I could no longer afford a seat.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, my father worked for an ad agency that purchased courtside boxes at the United States Open. Sometimes, when there were no clients around to be wooed, he took me instead.

headline.main: The U.S. Open, the Toughest Ticket in Town

abstract: Doctors often share their patients’ sorrow, but rarely their joys.
snippet: Doctors often share their patients’ sorrow, but rarely their joys.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — There wasn’t going to be a happy ending. The patient had metastatic cancer and had just gone through her third unsuccessful regimen of chemotherapy. Now it seemed that everywhere we looked, we found disease. An X-ray of her belly revealed an obstruction in her intestines. A CT scan of her chest uncovered a pulmonary embolism. Her labs demonstrated that she had almost no white blood cells left with which to defend herself.

abstract: Some people say it’s fun after we die and some people say it’s quiet.
snippet: Some people say it’s fun after we die and some people say it’s quiet.
lead_paragraph: Parenting Mistake #529: I promised my 5-year-old daughter, Sonya, that we could visit Grandma Joanie and Grandpa Roger “soon.”

headline.main: How to Talk to Kids About Death

abstract: When he talked about his work, I knew it meant he was giving me a window into his secret world.
snippet: When he talked about his work, I knew it meant he was giving me a window into his secret world.
lead_paragraph: My parents’ bedroom in my childhood home doubled as my dad’s neurosurgical haven, and it offered a glimpse into his work as a brain surgeon in the 1980s and ’90s. Various-size real human and primate skulls (available to medical students in the early 1970s), brain models and endless books surrounded their bedroom furniture. My mother, an artist, fed his passion and likened the room to his studio space, understanding that her husband’s true gallery was the operating room.

abstract: After years of dance, I turned against ballet and this sugarcoated fantasy. But my daughter helped change that.
snippet: After years of dance, I turned against ballet and this sugarcoated fantasy. But my daughter helped change that.
lead_paragraph: It’s “Nutcracker” season. Not again, I think. I am a recovering ballerina. I never danced professionally, but I did dream of it. I spent a lot of my childhood and early adolescence changing in and out of tights and leotards in dusty dressing rooms at various New York studios. I carried an oversize LeSportsac bag packed with balled-up tights, stray bobby pins, pointe shoes and even a special flammable shellac for hardening their tips.

abstract: My Korean father didn’t know how to play catch, or to tell me how he felt.
snippet: My Korean father didn’t know how to play catch, or to tell me how he felt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, N. J. — Football may be America’s most popular sport, but baseball is still where our hearts lie, especially this weekend when the season starts anew. Back in 1985, my own heart was firmly with the New York Mets. Most of my friends were Yankees fans, which was precisely why this immigrant teenager fell for the Mets: They needed my help. They won my loyalty when they lost the division to the St. Louis Cardinals that year, proving once again that misery loves company.

abstract: Her days as a tennis star were long gone.
snippet: Her days as a tennis star were long gone.
lead_paragraph: We were getting my mother ready for her big day. The indoor tennis facility in Maryland that she had helped build, and then managed for over 20 years, was being renamed in her honor by the Montgomery County Department of Parks. Hundreds of people were coming for the dedication ceremony. Billie Jean King would be there, so there was some cachet attached to the event. Billie Jean King was still somewhat famous. My mother, now 88, had also been famous, a long time ago. Still, this was better than never being famous at all. A dinner was planned at Bethesda Country Club. The day felt festive, like a wedding, people coming in from out of town, everyone getting prepared. I’d flown in from California the day before.

headline.main: For My Mother, One Last Grand Slam
headline.print_headline: For My Mother, One Last Grand Slam

abstract: Would my American sons look at Mexico the same way I did as a boy, with disdain?
snippet: Would my American sons look at Mexico the same way I did as a boy, with disdain?
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 1980, and I was 7 years old, when I traveled to America for the first time. I came to Los Angeles with my mom. The trip, which included visits to Disneyland and Sea World and Knott’s Berry Farm, was the reward my parents gave me for finishing first grade with honors. The Mexican middle class has always been as pampering in its affections as aspirational in its customs, and my family was no exception.

abstract: When I was 14, in 1972, girls took home ec and boys took shop. But I wanted to make lasagna, not birdhouses.
snippet: When I was 14, in 1972, girls took home ec and boys took shop. But I wanted to make lasagna, not birdhouses.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, I was hungry. Very hungry. After all, I was a 14-year-old boy. I played sports and was constantly working out. I could eat every hour. My mother packed my lunch in a grocery bag.

abstract: At 4 a.m., in the city that never sleeps, it’s just me and the raccoons.
snippet: At 4 a.m., in the city that never sleeps, it’s just me and the raccoons.
lead_paragraph: It’s not yet 4 a.m. and I’m out walking at a healthy clip. The moon is bright. In the distance, a subway train toots its horn, breaking the silence. A pair of ducks waddle through the mist across my path. Rounding the bend, I detect movement among the trees and notice a shadow lurching. I quicken my step, but then stop to see two large raccoons locked in a mating embrace. They give me a startled stare but then get back to business.

abstract: How the “most shocking moment in football history” looks, 30 years later.
snippet: How the “most shocking moment in football history” looks, 30 years later.
lead_paragraph: There has perhaps never been a more memorable play in football — or even all of American sports — than the one that ended the career of the Washington Redskins quarterback Joe Theismann, 30 years ago today. Since that play, N.F.L. quarterbacks have attempted nearly half a million passes, and we have never again seen (or heard) such skeletal trauma.

abstract: DEEP in a remote, fog-layered hollow near Sugar Grove, W.Va., hidden by fortress-like mountains, sits the country's largest eavesdropping bug. Located in a ''radio quiet'' zone, the station's large parabolic dishes secretly and silently sweep in millions of private telephone calls and e-mail messages an hour.     Run by the ultrasecret National Security Agency, the listening post intercepts all international communications entering the eastern United States. Another N.S.A. listening post, in Yakima,Wash., eavesdrops on the western half of the country.
snippet: DEEP in a remote, fog-layered hollow near Sugar Grove, W.Va., hidden by fortress-like mountains, sits the country's largest eavesdropping bug. Located in a ''radio quiet'' zone, the station's large parabolic dishes secretly and silently sweep in m...
lead_paragraph: Washington - DEEP in a remote, fog-layered hollow near Sugar Grove, W.Va., hidden by fortress-like mountains, sits the country's largest eavesdropping bug. Located in a "radio quiet" zone, the station's large parabolic dishes secretly and silently sweep in millions of private telephone calls and e-mail messages an hour.

headline.main: The Agency That Could Be Big Brother
headline.print_headline: THE NATION: Private Lives; The Agency That Could Be Big Brother

abstract: My prejudices against conservatives were just as uncompromising as the prejudices I’d often projected onto them.
snippet: My prejudices against conservatives were just as uncompromising as the prejudices I’d often projected onto them.
lead_paragraph: The trouble started the night Jeff, one of the guys I drink and talk about God with, announced that he’d been summoned to court for the Zimmerman trial jury pool. We’d kept politics out of our Wednesday night meetings, which are held on my back porch, the six of us seated at an old dining room table propped next to my broken hot tub (Florida short-sale homes come standard with broken hot tubs). Instead of Bible Study, we call it our Tavern Ministry, and while we were often drunk halfway through, a churchlike decorum had always held sway. Once the case came up, though, decorum collapsed.

headline.main: I Want to Be Friends With Republicans

abstract: The woman on the phone asking for money sounded just like me, and then she burst into tears.
snippet: The woman on the phone asking for money sounded just like me, and then she burst into tears.
lead_paragraph: URBANA, ILL. — The crime is known as the grandparent scam. It’s a type of identity theft that many people have been aware of for a while, but my grandfather had not heard about it before he fell prey to it.

abstract: I survived cancer, but many of the valiant women I met in support groups did not. I’ve tried to age well so I can honor them.
snippet: I survived cancer, but many of the valiant women I met in support groups did not. I’ve tried to age well so I can honor them.
lead_paragraph: I know the accepted wisdom: Making new friends takes longer as you age. After all, you’re busier, more set in your ways, less open to novelty.

abstract: Too many deaths have no meaning. I needed these animals’ lives to be part of the fight against H.I.V.
snippet: Too many deaths have no meaning. I needed these animals’ lives to be part of the fight against H.I.V.
lead_paragraph: The needle penetrated my latex glove and slipped into the soft skin of my finger. It was quick and painless. I was in the animal lab of Children’s Hospital Los Angeles, buried under Sunset Boulevard. Despite the thousands of mice within, the lab was peaceful. I was alone.

abstract: I was suffering from depression and insomnia. So I volunteered for a 24-hour suicide prevention hotline.
snippet: I was suffering from depression and insomnia. So I volunteered for a 24-hour suicide prevention hotline.
lead_paragraph: When I lived in New York after college, I suffered from depression and insomnia. So I volunteered for a 24-hour suicide prevention hotline.

abstract: A skateboard — that tool for falling, for failure — set me free from my mother.
snippet: A skateboard — that tool for falling, for failure — set me free from my mother.
lead_paragraph: GALIANO ISLAND, BRITISH COLUMBIA — I have broken my wrists, fingers, a tibia, a fibula, chipped a handful of teeth, cracked a vertebra and snapped a collarbone. I have concussed myself in Tallahassee, Fla., and Portland, Ore. I’ve skittered across the sooty hoods of New York cabs and bombed down many of San Francisco’s steepest avenues.

abstract: He still remembered his favorite flavors, even though everything else was gone.
snippet: He still remembered his favorite flavors, even though everything else was gone.
lead_paragraph: My father grew up in Perkasie, Pa., a Bucks County blip that has been twice decimated by fire; once in the 1890s, and once again in the 1980s. There’s a Dairy Queen near the center of town, by a ball field, and a historic carousel that whinnies to life only a few times a year. When you asked Dad to reminisce about his childhood, the first thing he’d mention and the only thing he’d talk about in real detail was that Dairy Queen. He especially loved some frozen drink called the Mr. Misty, which may have set the tone for a lifetime of adding honorifics to inanimate objects. When I was 15 I was humiliated — God, Dad! — when he popped his head into a sleepover, tossed me my favorite pillow, and announced that I’d forgotten Mr. Squishy.

abstract: If the drugs worked, I would never know if I might have been infected with H.I.V. or not.
snippet: If the drugs worked, I would never know if I might have been infected with H.I.V. or not.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a Modern Orthodox Jewish family in New Jersey, where my “sex talk,” at 13, came in the form of my mother handing me a book of anatomical comics. Inside it, she placed post-it notes to indicate her feelings. In the masturbation section: “God does not approve of this.” In the gay sex section: “Definitely not.”

abstract: What does it mean when your parents split up — after you’ve already grown up?
snippet: What does it mean when your parents split up — after you’ve already grown up?
lead_paragraph: BOLINAS, CALIF. — Two years ago, my mother called.

abstract: Cardboard and postage stamps: mementos from my trip around the world.
snippet: Cardboard and postage stamps: mementos from my trip around the world.
lead_paragraph: Four Septembers ago, my husband and I were bundled up in a yurt in the Gobi Desert at the end of a trip around the world. Our journey had included 21 countries, both one- and two-humped camels, swims in the Nile and the Euphrates, and an escape from a herd of wild elephants. It had also included at least a dozen visits to the post offices of the world.

abstract: Little by little, the slow third-world bus of my demons had been making its way back to me.
snippet: Little by little, the slow third-world bus of my demons had been making its way back to me.
lead_paragraph: I told the psychiatrist I was depressed. “Have you ever thought of killing yourself?” she said. I could see her getting ready to check off “Poses danger to self or others” and send me away, the way my oldest brother had once been sent away, with a diagnosis of schizophrenia, and dosed heavily with Thorazine. Come to think of it, maybe he committed himself, but I know the part about the Thorazine was right. I stole one of his pills once, ate it and got into the shower, and almost passed out on the tiles.

abstract: Here was my father, giver of values, such as they were.
snippet: Here was my father, giver of values, such as they were.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, CALIF. — During a recent trip to Los Angeles, a traffic jam forced me to reroute through Culver City. How could I not take a few minutes to see what had become of 10136 Venice Boulevard?

headline.main: How a Gambling Addict Became a Bookie

abstract: Can we trust our own memories?
snippet: Can we trust our own memories?
lead_paragraph: Can we trust our own memories?

abstract: Councilman David Yassky doesn't mind immersing himself in a topic that inspires most constituents to hold their noses: garbage.
snippet: Councilman David Yassky doesn't mind immersing himself in a topic that inspires most constituents to hold their noses: garbage.
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS because he's a sloppy fellow whose daughters, borrowing a Yiddish word from their grandmother, accuse him of creating a hekdesh (messy house) wherever he goes, Councilman David Yassky doesn't mind immersing himself in a topic that inspires most constituents to hold their noses: garbage.

headline.main: A Councilman Who Has His Own Ideas About Garbage
headline.print_headline: A Councilman Who Has His Own Ideas About Garbage

abstract: My son — but also, my toothbrush, my computer and a knife.
snippet: My son — but also, my toothbrush, my computer and a knife.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — I was getting ready for bed when I heard sirens. No big deal in the city, right? We hear them all the time. I brushed my teeth — they got louder. Tossed my pants on the bathroom floor — louder, closer, and when I went into the living room I saw red lights slicing through the blinds.

headline.main: What Would You Grab in a Fire?
headline.print_headline: What Would You Grab in a Fire?

abstract: It wasn’t about pronunciation or conjugating verbs. It was about starting over.
snippet: It wasn’t about pronunciation or conjugating verbs. It was about starting over.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, MISS. — I once spent two years as a high school French teacher. I took the post because I was divorcing and needed a paycheck. The school took me even though I had no teaching experience because, under Mississippi law, if a school is hard up for a teacher, it can hire anyone the state designates an “expert citizen.”

abstract: Seeing an old landscape through a newborn’s eyes.
snippet: Seeing an old landscape through a newborn’s eyes.
lead_paragraph: We expected the baby in June, and our lease ended in July. Under the best of circumstances, I dread packing. To move is to endure a weekslong confrontation with your past selves and their poor consumer choices. You reckon with useless gifts retained from guilt, find birthday cards from the deceased. Now we were adding all that to the triage of newborn care.

abstract: Growing up black in Mississippi, I learned that the country’s racist history doesn’t just flow beneath the present; it drags us with it.
snippet: Growing up black in Mississippi, I learned that the country’s racist history doesn’t just flow beneath the present; it drags us with it.
lead_paragraph: DeLisle, Miss.

abstract: It seems that all my life we have been bombing someone, teaching them a lesson. Every day I understand more deeply how violent we are.
snippet: It seems that all my life we have been bombing someone, teaching them a lesson. Every day I understand more deeply how violent we are.
lead_paragraph: DELAWARE, Ohio —

abstract: Nothing says mortality like the realization that you will live only long enough to use up 3.2 percent of your office supplies.
snippet: Nothing says mortality like the realization that you will live only long enough to use up 3.2 percent of your office supplies.
lead_paragraph: By the time we reach our 50s, most of us have experienced a moment when, for the first time, we truly confront our mortality, a moment when it suddenly and forcefully comes home to us that we ourselves personally actually are going to die — as in: be dead — someday. This revelation can be produced under varied circumstances: It happens for one person upon the death of a friend, a contemporary; for another while he or she reads “Four Quartets”:

abstract: It was my last chance to have a baby, after a life filled with complicated family relationships. I had been on my own since the age of 16.
snippet: It was my last chance to have a baby, after a life filled with complicated family relationships. I had been on my own since the age of 16.
lead_paragraph: A marriage proposal for a woman at 38 is rarely really a marriage proposal. Or, rather, it’s not a choice of two people; it’s a choice of child or no child. It’s a last chance.

abstract: The only way I could get through to my nephew, suddenly a quadriplegic, was with the dark, dirgy music.
snippet: The only way I could get through to my nephew, suddenly a quadriplegic, was with the dark, dirgy music.
lead_paragraph: I arrived home from the Shepherd Center in Atlanta — a “catastrophic care hospital” — debilitated by grief. I had many questions stemming from our family’s new reality, but only one that I would work to answer: What should I include on a soundtrack for recovery for my formerly active and able-bodied 23-year-old nephew who had just become a quadriplegic? I sifted through my iTunes and the pile of neglected CDs shoved to the back of my closet with a clarity of purpose and swollen eyes. There wasn’t much else I could do.

abstract: The sight of her bare body made me as dizzy as the sight of my own blood. It was too much truth.
snippet: The sight of her bare body made me as dizzy as the sight of my own blood. It was too much truth.
lead_paragraph: My mother had invited us on an all-expense-paid beach vacation at a resort in France. There was just one problem. As I told my sons in our living room, “It’s a nude resort.”

headline.main: Vacationing in the Nude, With Mom

abstract: I imagined the sonogram: a grainy image of the fetus, and then a thumping sound, like a signal from deep space.
snippet: I imagined the sonogram: a grainy image of the fetus, and then a thumping sound, like a signal from deep space.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — During the six years I begged my husband to get me pregnant, I kept certain images locked away in a mental hope chest. The first was the moment of conception — one of those lazy Sunday afternoons, post-brunch and newspaper, pre-dinner and a compelling HBO lineup, the two of us resting atop rumpled sheets.

abstract: Both leaning in and leaning back have proved to be harder than I expected.
snippet: Both leaning in and leaning back have proved to be harder than I expected.
lead_paragraph: If I’m lucky, I might have as long as two hours to work. I riffle through the stack of research articles on substance use, pull out a few relevant ones, and begin revising my paper’s introduction. I’ve just gotten in the groove when a sweet singsong voice drifts over from the room next door: “Mommy, I have to go to the baaaa-throom!”

abstract: One hot day in another country, I failed to help a thirsty man.
snippet: One hot day in another country, I failed to help a thirsty man.
lead_paragraph: Boulder, Colo.

headline.main: A Bottle of Water in Brazzaville

abstract: I got an extra day — just an average day — with my father.
snippet: I got an extra day — just an average day — with my father.
lead_paragraph: In late August, I got an extra day — just an average day — with my father.

abstract: Clothes weren’t just indulgences. They were armor.
snippet: Clothes weren’t just indulgences. They were armor.
lead_paragraph: My mother used to dress up for airports and emergency rooms. When I was 3 and cracked my forehead open on a doorjamb, she had me change — I believe into a smocked white dress, an interesting choice for a child with a head wound — before we drove to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian.

abstract: How to misplace a family member forever, without really noticing.
snippet: How to misplace a family member forever, without really noticing.
lead_paragraph: Call this a Chicago story. It’s true, though I’ve never understood why that matters. It seems a cheap way of looking at a story, to judge it by whether or not it actually occurred. The only question is: Does it rattle the soul or doesn’t it?

abstract: I’m bad with faces. But it’s not my fault.
snippet: I’m bad with faces. But it’s not my fault.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Imagine entering the boardroom and meeting for the first time each of the company’s 15 directors. These are important people in your life; you’ll be expected to recognize them when you next meet.

abstract: Not as much as my memories.
snippet: Not as much as my memories.
lead_paragraph: My mother said the book would be valuable one day. Her only regret was that over the years of reading it to me and my sister, she had been careless about pulling it off the shelf and had torn the delicate red leather of the spine. Still, it was a first English edition of “Winnie-the-Pooh,” dated 1926. Slim, soft and well loved, it was the copy she had had as a child and when she died, she left it to me.

headline.main: How Much Is This Old Thing Worth?

abstract: The death of my wife exiled me from what had been my life.
snippet: The death of my wife exiled me from what had been my life.
lead_paragraph: “In the middle of our life’s journey, I found myself in a dark wood.”

headline.main: I Found Myself in a Dark Wood
headline.print_headline: I Found Myself in a Dark Wood

abstract: My mother named me after Kris Kristofferson. Could I saddle my son with a famous name?
snippet: My mother named me after Kris Kristofferson. Could I saddle my son with a famous name?
lead_paragraph: My wife gave birth to our first child this April. When you tell people that you’re expecting, the second question they ask (after the gender) is, “Do you have a name picked out?” Because we make a living working with books, my wife and I take the business of naming seriously, and our friends seemed to expect us to pluck a name from literary obscurity.

abstract: I felt I had only a limited amount of creative energy, and was afraid of wasting it on ‘women’s work.’
snippet: I felt I had only a limited amount of creative energy, and was afraid of wasting it on ‘women’s work.’
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when I was in the midst of treatment for breast cancer, Susan, a dear friend, showed up on my doorstep with a bag of yarn and two wooden needles. “I am going to teach you to knit,” she announced. “This is what got me through my own horrible year of treatment.”

headline.main: Why Should Cancer Make Me Want to Knit?

abstract: My up-and-down relationship with a pit bull mix named Pavlov.
snippet: My up-and-down relationship with a pit bull mix named Pavlov.
lead_paragraph: On our second date, eight months before my nervous breakdown, I met her 85-pound pit bull mix, Pavlov. I’d just parked my blue motor scooter in her driveway, feeling jittery but intent to woo, when I noticed the beast galloping across the lawn at me — eyes wide, hackles raised and an I’m-going-to-disfigure-you huff with every trampling of the grass.

abstract: As an astronomer, maybe I found distant galaxies easier to understand than the people around me.
snippet: As an astronomer, maybe I found distant galaxies easier to understand than the people around me.
lead_paragraph: Edinburgh

abstract: My father told me that my grandmother lived not far from me in San Francisco. This was news: I’d last seen her almost 25 years before.
snippet: My father told me that my grandmother lived not far from me in San Francisco. This was news: I’d last seen her almost 25 years before.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother has Alzheimer’s disease. But in a lot of ways, she made us forget each other a long time ago.

abstract: I spent my high school years pretending to be someone else. So how could I call the reunion my own?
snippet: I spent my high school years pretending to be someone else. So how could I call the reunion my own?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I found myself shifting nervously in the driver’s seat of a parked rental car and avoiding the rearview mirror, afraid I’d catch a disquieting glimpse of my adolescent self glaring back. I’ve never come entirely to grips with him — or rather, I’ve never entirely forgiven him his lies and his cowardice. And now that I was about to walk into my 20-year high school reunion, his ghost was unbearably palpable.

abstract: The truth about my grandmother’s Puerto Rican childhood.
snippet: The truth about my grandmother’s Puerto Rican childhood.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother was raised in Vega Baja, Puerto Rico. She said the name, Vega Baja, meaning the “low plains,” with such romance that it was clear she longed for the place. In her stories she described a big house, and a farm where the children could eat the fruit from the trees and learned to milk a cow. Every Sunday after church they went to the beach. She taught herself to swim because the other children always played in the deep water and she hated being left behind.

headline.main: The Other Side of the Living Sea
headline.print_headline: The Other Side of the Living Sea

abstract: The language he spoke is leaving me now. And he is leaving me, too.
snippet: The language he spoke is leaving me now. And he is leaving me, too.
lead_paragraph: The 18th-century Italian philosopher Giambattista Vico believed that as a civilization progressed, it lost touch with its creative origins. An ancient warrior would never declare “I’m angry”; he would wax metaphorical with “my blood boils.” The Roman poet Horace went a step further, believing that when words died they took memories with them. Just as forests change their leaves each year, so, too, do words: new languages “bloom and thrive” but only after “the old race dies.”

headline.main: Speaking to My Father in a Dead Dialect

abstract: I believed completely in a woman’s right to choose, but I didn’t know what a brutal choice it was.
snippet: I believed completely in a woman’s right to choose, but I didn’t know what a brutal choice it was.
lead_paragraph: I had just turned 22 and I had the self-esteem of a squashed toad. This may explain why I was having an affair with a married 36-year-old sound mixer whom I’d met on a film shoot a couple of months earlier.

headline.main: I Couldn’t Turn My Abortion Into Art

abstract: I visited him in prison when I was 9. Then I went back as an adult.
snippet: I visited him in prison when I was 9. Then I went back as an adult.
lead_paragraph: Of all the troubling events from my childhood, one of the most enduring remains the afternoon I visited a prisoner serving a life sentence for murder. It was 1978 and I was 9 years old, escorted to Western Penitentiary in Pittsburgh by my mother, who, compelled by a lifelong objective of raising her son’s awareness of injustice in the world, no doubt considered this to be a well-suited occasion.

abstract: Watching Hurricane Sandy roll in, from the windows of our son’s hospital room.
snippet: Watching Hurricane Sandy roll in, from the windows of our son’s hospital room.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, when Hurricane Sandy struck New York City, our son, William, was heavily sedated in St. Luke’s Hospital in Manhattan, never conscious of the storm outside or its aftermath.

abstract: I was a master. He was a servant. This was what I’d been taught.
snippet: I was a master. He was a servant. This was what I’d been taught.
lead_paragraph: When I was 6, I saw my uncle slap, punch and kick the young boy who lived in his house. This wasn’t unusual in the India of the early ’90s, and it isn’t unusual even now. Parents routinely beat up kids, convinced that it is the best way to discipline them. A friend of mine in Gangtok, my hometown, came to school with stick marks tattooed on his arms every other week. This, though, was the first time that I had actually seen my uncle beating up a child.

abstract: “Gone With the Wind” was my “Twilight.”
snippet: “Gone With the Wind” was my “Twilight.”
lead_paragraph: When I was in middle school, I read Margaret Mitchell’s epic romance, “Gone With the Wind.” Not once. Not twice. But continuously. Each time I finished the novel, I began again, flipping open the broken-spined paperback so many times the book split in half, yielding two portable sections of text. I preferred a break of at least several hours between readings, but sometimes compulsion forced me to begin again only moments after finishing it.

abstract: My only hope was that the love would die slowly, so slowly I might not notice.
snippet: My only hope was that the love would die slowly, so slowly I might not notice.
lead_paragraph: We wrote our vows the day before our wedding, sitting on a rock. I was pregnant, and beside me, shuddering in the wind, was my little plastic grocery bag of Ritz crackers, cereal bars and ginger ale. The bag went everywhere with me, even to the jewelry store where Tyler and I bought the rings, and if I ate and sipped at a steady pace I could keep the vomiting down to about four times a day.

abstract: Growing up hungry in rural China in the 1970s.
snippet: Growing up hungry in rural China in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: What did Spring Festival mean to a child like me, growing up in rural China in the early 1970s, in the aftermath of the Cultural Revolution? Chocolate? Not at a time when even table sugar was a luxury good. We hadn’t even heard of chocolate. Candy? Impossible. How could a poor family like ours, which was never even issued the official ration coupons, purchase it? Rice, then? No, not even that.

abstract: Can we trust our own memories?
snippet: Can we trust our own memories?
lead_paragraph: Can we trust our own memories?

abstract: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
snippet: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
lead_paragraph: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
